title: California Consumer Privacy Act
content:
{{short description|California data privacy law}}
{{Infobox U.S. State legislation
| State = California
| Full_name = California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018<ref>{{cite web |title=AB-375, Chau. Privacy: personal information: businesses. |url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180AB375 |website=[[California State Legislature]] |accessdate=19 November 2018}}</ref>
| Status = current
| Introduced = January 3, 2018
| Signed = June 28, 2018
| Governor = [[Jerry Brown]]
| Code = [[California Civil Code]]
| Section = 1798.100
| Resolution = AB-375 (2017–2018 Session)
| URL = {{URL|1=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180AB375|2=Assembly Bill No. 375}}
}}
The '''California Consumer Privacy Act''' ('''CCPA''') is a [[State law (United States)|state statute]] intended to enhance [[privacy]] rights and [[consumer protection]] for residents of the state of [[California]] in the [[United States]]. The bill was passed by the [[California State Legislature]] and signed into law by the Governor of California, [[Jerry Brown]], on June 28, 2018, to amend Part 4 of Division 3 of the [[California Civil Code]].<ref name="legislation">[https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180AB375 The California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018].</ref> Officially called '''AB-375''', the act was introduced by [[Ed Chau]], member of the California State Assembly, and State Senator [[Robert Hertzberg]].<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/story/california-unanimously-passes-historic-privacy-bill/|title=California Unanimously Passes Historic Privacy Bill|last=Lapowsky|first=Issie|date=June 28, 2018|work=Wired|accessdate=September 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180AB375|title=Bill Text - AB-375 Privacy: personal information: businesses.|website=Leginfo.legislature.ca.gov|accessdate=27 November 2018}}</ref>

Amendments to the CCPA, in the form of Senate Bill 1121, were passed on September 13, 2018.<ref name="SB-1121">{{Cite web|url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180SB1121|title=Bill Text - SB-1121 California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018.|website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov|access-date=2019-01-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.information-management.com/opinion/how-the-new-california-data-privacy-act-could-impact-all-organizations|title=How the new California data privacy act could impact all organizations|website=Information Management|language=en|access-date=2019-01-30|archive-date=2019-01-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190131040247/https://www.information-management.com/opinion/how-the-new-california-data-privacy-act-could-impact-all-organizations|url-status=dead}}</ref> Additional substantive amendments were signed into law on October 11, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.ca.gov/2019/10/11/governor-newsom-issues-legislative-update-10-11-19/https://www.gov.ca.gov/2019/10/11/governor-newsom-issues-legislative-update-10-11-19/|title=Governor Newsom Issues Legislative Update 10.11.19|date=12 October 2019 |language=en|access-date=2019-11-08}}</ref> The CCPA became effective on January 1, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.natlawreview.com/article/2019-year-ccpa-infographic|title=2019 is the Year of . . . CCPA? [Infographic]|date=January 8, 2019|website=The National Law Review|language=en|access-date=2019-01-30}}</ref> In November 2020, California voters passed [[2020 California Proposition 24|Proposition 24]], also known as the [[California Privacy Rights Act]], which amends and expands the CCPA.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Move Over, CCPA: The California Privacy Rights Act Gets the Spotlight Now|url=https://news.bloomberglaw.com/privacy-and-data-security/move-over-ccpa-the-california-privacy-rights-act-gets-the-spotlight-now|access-date=2020-12-10|website=news.bloomberglaw.com|language=en}}</ref>

==Intentions of the Act==

The intentions of the Act are to provide California residents with the right to:
# Know what [[personal data]] is being collected about them.
# Know whether their personal data is sold or disclosed and to whom.
# Say no to the sale of personal data.
# Access their personal data.
# Request a business to delete any personal information about a consumer collected from that consumer.<ref>Senate Bill No. 1120, Chapter 735, Sec.2, 1798.105</ref>
# Not be discriminated against for exercising their [[privacy]] rights.

=== Compliance ===
The CCPA applies to any business, including any for-profit entity that collects consumers' personal data, does business in California, and satisfies at least one of the following thresholds:

* Has annual [[gross revenue]]s in excess of $25 million; 
* Buys, receives, or sells the personal information of 100,000 or more consumers or households; or 
* Earns more than half of its annual revenue from selling consumers' personal information.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oag.ca.gov/system/files/attachments/press_releases/CCPA%20Fact%20Sheet%20%2800000002%29.pdf|title=California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) Fact Sheet|website=State of California - Department of Justice - Office of the Attorney General|language=en|access-date=2020-03-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/ccpa-guide-are-you-covered-by-the-ccpa-38771/|title=CCPA Guide: Are You Covered by the CCPA|website=JD Supra|language=en|access-date=2019-01-30}}</ref>

Organizations are required to "implement and maintain reasonable security procedures and practices" in protecting [[Customer data|consumer data]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=CIV&sectionNum=1798.150.|title=TITLE 1.81.5. California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 - CA Legislative Information}}</ref>

The businesses that the CCPA refers to do not need to be physically present in California. As long as the business is active in the state and meets the requirements, they are considered to be under the CCPA. This includes transactions done on the Internet. In comparison to other privacy laws like the GDPR, the CCPA lacks clarity about its geographic range.<ref>{{cite journal |id={{ProQuest|2350105509}} |last1=Illman |first1=Erin |last2=Temple |first2=Paul |title=California Consumer Privacy Act: What Companies Need to Know |journal=The Business Lawyer |volume=75 |issue=1 |date=Winter 2020 |pages=1637–1646 }}</ref>

=== Responsibility and accountability ===

* Implement processes to obtain [[Parental consent|parental or guardian consent]] for minors under 13 years and the affirmative consent of minors between 13 and 16 years to data sharing for purposes (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.120(c)).
* "Do Not Sell My Personal Information" link on the [[home page]] of the website of the business, that will direct users to a web page enabling them, or someone they authorize, to opt out of the sale of the resident's personal information (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.135(a)(1)).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.caprivacy.org/facts/information-control|title=Control Your Personal Information {{!}} CA Consumer Privacy Act|website=caprivacy.org|access-date=2019-01-30|archive-date=2019-01-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190131040537/https://www.caprivacy.org/facts/information-control|url-status=dead}}</ref>
* Designate methods for submitting data access requests, including, at a minimum, a [[toll-free telephone number]]  (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.130(a)).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.com/corpcounsel/2018/12/18/a-practical-guide-to-ccpa-readiness-implementing-calif-s-new-privacy-law-part-2/|title=A Practical Guide to CCPA Readiness: Implementing Calif.'s New Privacy Law (Part 2)|last1=Valetk|first1=Harry A.|date=December 18, 2018|first2=Brian|last2=Hengesbaugh|website=Corporate Counsel|language=en|access-date=2019-01-30}}</ref>
* Update privacy policies with newly required information, including a description of California residents' rights (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.135(a)(2)).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billCompareClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180AB375|title=Today's Law As Amended|website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov|access-date=2019-01-30}}</ref>
* Avoid requesting opt-in consent for 12 months after a California resident opts out (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.135(a)(5)).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90178906/5-key-things-in-californias-new-privacy-law|title=Here are 5 key details in California's new privacy law|last=Captain|first=Sean|date=2018-07-02|website=Fast Company|language=en-US|access-date=2019-01-30}}</ref>

=== Sanctions and remedies ===
The following sanctions and remedies can be imposed:

* Companies, activists, associations, and others can be authorized to exercise opt-out rights on behalf of California residents (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.135(c).<ref name="SB-1121" />
* Companies that become victims of data theft or other data security breaches can be ordered in civil class action lawsuits to pay statutory damages between $100 and $750 per California resident and incident, or actual damages, whichever is greater, and any other relief a court deems proper, subject to an option of the California Attorney General's Office to prosecute the company instead of allowing civil suits to be brought against it (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.150).<ref name="SB-1121" />
* A fine up to $7,500 for each intentional violation and $2,500 for each unintentional violation (Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.155).<ref name="SB-1121" />
* Privacy notices must be accessible and have alternative format access clearly called out.<ref>{{cite web |title=Federal accessibility laws don't matter — California's accessibility laws do |url=https://medium.com/@sheribyrnehaber/federal-accessibility-laws-dont-matter-california-s-accessibility-laws-do-7367e32755ca |website=Medium.com |accessdate=12 November 2018}}</ref>
* Liability may also apply in respect of businesses in overseas countries who ship items into California.<ref>{{cite web |title=How does the California Consumer Privacy Act apply to Australian businesses?|url=https://www.gladwinlegal.com.au/how-does-the-california-consumer-privacy-act-apply-to-australian-businesses/ |website=www.gladwinlegal.com.au |date=12 August 2020 |accessdate=24 August 2020}}</ref>

The CCPA differs from the [[Virginia Consumer Data Protection Act]] in that the former provides a [[private right of action]], whereas the latter is enforced by the [[Attorney General of Virginia|Attorney General]]'s office.<ref>{{cite web|title=Virginia passes the Consumer Data Protection Act|first=Sarah|last=Rippy|publisher=[[International Association of Privacy Professionals]]|date=March 3, 2021|accessdate=March 8, 2023|url=https://iapp.org/news/a/virginia-passes-the-consumer-data-protection-act/}}</ref>

==Definition of personal data==
CCPA defines personal information as information that identifies, relates to, describes, is reasonably capable of being associated with, or could reasonably be linked (directly or indirectly) with a particular consumer or [[household]] such as a real name, alias, postal address, unique personal identifier, online identifier, Internet Protocol address, email address, account name, social security number, driver's license number, license plate number, passport number, or other similar identifiers.<ref name="legislation" />

An additional caveat identifies, relates to, describes, or is capable of being associated with, a particular individual, including, but not limited to, their name, signature, Social Security number, physical characteristics or description, address, telephone number, passport number, driver's license or state identification card number, insurance policy number, education, employment, employment history, bank account number, credit card number, debit card number, or any other financial information, medical information, or health insurance information.<ref name="personal information">{{cite act |type=Law |index=DIVISION 3. OBLIGATIONS [1427 - 3273] e |date= January 1, 2010|article= |article-type=|legislature=California State Legislature |title=TITLE 1.81. CUSTOMER RECORDS[1798.80 - 1798.84]|trans-title= |page=|url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?sectionNum=1798.80.&lawCode=CIV |language=en}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>

It does not consider ''Publicly Available Information'' as personal.<ref name="law">{{cite act |type=Assembly Bill |index=1798.140/(o)(2) |date=June 28, 2018 |article= |article-type= |legislature=California State Legislature |title=Privacy: personal information: businesses. |trans-title= |page= |url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180AB375 |language=en}}</ref>
 
Key differences between CCPA and the European Union's [[General Data Protection Regulation]] (GDPR) include the scope and territorial reach of each, definitions related to protected information, levels of specificity, and an opt-out right for sales of personal information.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cgoc.com/blog-how-to-prepare-for-the-ccpa-here-are-the-resources-you-need/|title=How to Prepare for the CCPA – Here Are the Resources You Need|date=2019-10-06|website=CGOC The Council|access-date=2019-10-15|archive-date=2019-10-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191009055717/https://www.cgoc.com/blog-how-to-prepare-for-the-ccpa-here-are-the-resources-you-need/|url-status=dead}}</ref> CCPA differs in definition of personal information from GDPR as in some cases the CCPA only considers data that was provided by a consumer. The GDPR does not make that distinction and covers all personal data regardless of source. In the event of sensitive personal information, this does not apply if the information was manifestly made public by the data subject themselves, following the exception under Art.9(2),e). As such, the definition in GDPR is much broader than defined in the CCPA.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fielding |first1=John |title=Four differences between the GDPR and the CCPA |url=https://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2019/02/04/gdpr-ccpa-differences/ |publisher=HelpNet Security |date=Feb 4, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cgoc.com/blog-how-to-prepare-for-the-ccpa-here-are-the-resources-you-need/|title=How to Prepare for the CCPA – Here Are the Resources You Need|date=2019-10-08|website=CGOC|access-date=2019-10-08|archive-date=2019-10-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191009055717/https://www.cgoc.com/blog-how-to-prepare-for-the-ccpa-here-are-the-resources-you-need/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="Skiera Miller Jin 2022 p. ">{{cite book |last=Skiera |first=Bernd |last2=Miller |first2=Klaus, M. |last3=Jin |first3=Yuxi |title=The Impact of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) on the Online Advertising Market |publisher=Bernd Skiera |publication-place=La Vergne |date=2022 |isbn=978-3-9824173-3-2 |oclc=1301513718 |page={{page needed|date=March 2023}}}}</ref>

Personal data can also include online or social media profile information. Personal data is not limited to a number or a physical document but can also be online identities, accounts, and other personal information.

== History ==
The California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 was originally proposed as a [[California ballot proposition|ballot proposition]] by a privacy group known as Californians for Consumer Privacy.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wakabayashi|first=Daisuke|date=14 May 2018|title=Silicon Valley Faces Regulatory Fight on Its Home Turf|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/13/business/california-data-privacy-ballot-measure.html}}</ref> The [[California Department of Justice|California DOJ]] approved the initiative's official language on December 18, 2017, allowing the group to begin collecting signatures.<ref>{{cite press release|date=18 December 2017|title=Proposed Initiative Enters Circulation: Establishes New Consumer Privacy Rights; Expands Liability For Consumer Data Breaches|url=https://www.sos.ca.gov/administration/news-releases-and-advisories/2017-news-releases-and-advisories/proposed-initiative-enters-circulation39/|publisher=[[California Secretary of State]]}}</ref> In June 2018, the proponents gathered enough signatures to qualify the CCPA initiative for the November 2018 election.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The California Privacy Rights Act Has Passed: What's in It?|url=https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/the-california-privacy-rights-act-has-49371/|access-date=2020-12-10|website=JD Supra|language=en}}</ref> In California, the state legislature cannot repeal or amend a ballot proposition once it is passed by voters.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Laws governing the initiative process in California|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Laws_governing_the_initiative_process_in_California|access-date=2020-12-10|website=Ballotpedia|language=en}}</ref> In response to the CCPA ballot proposition, state legislators negotiated with Californians for Consumer Privacy to pass a less restrictive version of the CCPA in exchange for the withdrawal of the ballot proposition.<ref>{{Cite web|last=  |first=  |date=2018-06-22|title=California lawmakers agree to new consumer privacy rules that would avert showdown on the November ballot|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-privacy-initiative-legislature-agreement-20180621-story.html|access-date=2020-12-10|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}}</ref>

The CCPA was passed by the state legislature and signed by Gov. [[Jerry Brown|Brown]] on June 28, 2018; it became effective on January 1, 2020.<ref>{{Cite magazine|title=California Unanimously Passes Historic Privacy Bill|language=en-us|magazine=Wired|url=https://www.wired.com/story/california-unanimously-passes-historic-privacy-bill/|access-date=2020-12-10|issn=1059-1028}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Stephens |first=John |date=2 July 2019 |title=California Consumer Privacy Act |url=https://www.americanbar.org/groups/business_law/publications/committee_newsletters/bcl/2019/201902/fa_9/ |magazine=Business and Corporate Litigation Committee Newsletter |publisher=[[American Bar Association]] }}</ref> The act's effect was dependent upon the withdrawal of [[Popular initiative|initiative]] 17–0039, the Consumer Right to Privacy Act.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://clsbluesky.law.columbia.edu/2018/07/23/sullivan-cromwell-discusses-california-consumer-privacy-act-of-2018/ |title=Sullivan & Cromwell Discusses California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 |last1=Cohen |first1=Rodgin |last2=Evangelakos |first2=John |last3=Mousavi |first3=Nader |last4=Schwartz |first4=Matthew |last5=Friedlander |first5=Nicole |date=23 July 2018 |website=CLS Blue Sky Blog |publisher=[[Columbia Law School]] }}</ref> Five amendments were enacted and signed by Gov. [[Gavin Newsom|Newsom]] on October 11, 2019.<ref name="natlawreview2019">{{cite web |url=https://www.natlawreview.com/article/california-consumer-privacy-act-effective-january-1-update |title=California Consumer Privacy Act Effective January 1: Update|last1=Das |first1=Anjali |last2=Ferrari |first2=Stefanie |date=3 December 2019 |publisher=[[The National Law Review]] }}</ref> Notice of [[California Department of Justice|DOJ]]'s proposed regulations was also published October 11 in the [[California Regulatory Notice Register|Z Register]]; {{as of|2020|1|10|df=US}} the [[California Office of Administrative Law|OAL]] had not yet filed the final regulations with the [[Secretary of State of California|Secretary of State]], as required for the regulations to become effective.<ref name="natlawreview2019" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.adlawaccess.com/2019/10/articles/ccpa-draft-regulations-what-to-know-about-timing-and-process/ |title=CCPA Draft Regulations: What to Know About Timing and Process |last1=Hutnik |first1=Alysa Zeltzer |last2=Townley |first2=Katie |last3=Khouryanna |first3=DiPrima |date=23 October 2019 |website=Ad Law Access }}</ref>

The [[California Privacy Rights Act|California Privacy Rights Act of 2020]] proposed several changes to the CCPA.<ref>{{Cite web|title=California Proposition 24, Consumer Personal Information Law and Agency Initiative (2020)|url=https://ballotpedia.org/California_Proposition_24,_Consumer_Personal_Information_Law_and_Agency_Initiative_(2020)|access-date=2020-10-25|website=Ballotpedia|language=en}}</ref> The Act, also known as 2020 California Proposition 24, expands existing data privacy laws by allowing consumers greater control of their personal data and establishing the [[California Privacy Protection Agency]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Text of Proposed Laws - Proposition 24|url=https://vig.cdn.sos.ca.gov/2020/general/pdf/topl-prop24.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201018200407/https://vig.cdn.sos.ca.gov/2020/general/pdf/topl-prop24.pdf |archive-date=2020-10-18 |access-date=|website=California Secretary of State}}</ref> It passed, with a majority of voters approving the measure.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Hooks|first=Chris Nichols, Kris|title=What We Know About California Proposition Results|url=https://www.capradio.org/158690|access-date=2020-12-08|website=www.capradio.org}}</ref>

== Exemptions ==

* Personal Health Information<ref name=":1" />
* Financial information

A big area of the CCPA exemption is the personal health information (PHI) that is gathered.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|date=2019-10-10|title=California Consumer Privacy Act FAQs for Covered Businesses|url=https://www.jacksonlewis.com/publication/california-consumer-privacy-act-faqs-covered-businesses|access-date=2020-11-11|website=Jackson Lewis|language=en}}</ref> Rather than the data being treated with the CCPA guidelines in mind, it is expected for PHI to adhere to the [[Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act]], otherwise known as HIPAA.<ref name=":0" /> If the business collecting the data is related to clinical trials, then it must adhere to the "Common Rule".<ref>{{Cite web|title=The California Consumer Privacy Act|url=https://bakerlaw.com/webfiles/Privacy/2019/Briefs/California-Consumer-Privacy-Act-FAQs.pdf}}</ref>

As for the information that is gathered by financial institutions, the institutions follow the California Financial Information Privacy act or the [[Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act]] depending on the situation.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|title=Codes Display Text|url=http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displayText.xhtml?division=1.4.&lawCode=FIN|access-date=2020-11-11|website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov}}</ref>
